2. 'Today YOU write the word problems! You will create one for each operation.'
3. Model: 'For addition, I might write: Mom baked 8 cookies. Dad baked 6 more. How many cookies altogether?'
4. The child writes one word problem for each: addition, subtraction, multiplication, division.
5. Exchange problems with the parent. Each person solves the other's problems.
6. Check answers together.
7. The child rates the difficulty of their own problems: easy, medium, or challenging.

slides.heading: Create Your Own Word Problems
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at this fun title! It says "Create Your Own Word Problems." That means today, *you* get to be the super smart math person who makes up stories with numbers, and the awesome writer who tells those stories! It's like being a math detective and a story wizard all at once!

slides.setup_instructions: Provide paper divided into 4 sections, one for each operation. Have counters available for solving.
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at all the cool things we need for our math adventure today! We have paper to write our stories on, a pencil to draw the words, and these little counters are like tiny friends that help us count. We also have special cards for each math idea we'll use. Ask your grown-up to help you find these things so we can get started!

slides.text: 'You have been solving word problems all week. Now it is time to WRITE them! You are the mathematician AND the author.'
slides.mascot_explanation: You know how we've been solving stories with numbers? Well, guess what? Today, *you* get to be the one to make up those stories! You're going to be a super smart mathematician and a fantastic author, writing your very own math adventures. Get ready to use your amazing brain!

slides.text: 'For addition, think of a story where things COME TOGETHER. For subtraction, a story where things GO AWAY.'
slides.mascot_explanation: For our first math story, let's think about adding! That's when things come together, like when you get more toys or when friends join your game. So, for addition, we'll make a story where things are getting bigger or joining up.

slides.text: 'For multiplication, think about GROUPS of the same number. For division, think about SHARING equally.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, for our next math stories, let's think about subtraction and other ideas! For subtraction, we'll make a story where things go away, like when you eat a yummy cookie. For multiplication, we’ll think about groups of the same thing, and for division, we’ll make a story about sharing fairly with friends.

slides.text: 'Write your problem clearly so someone else can understand and solve it. Include a question at the end!'
slides.mascot_explanation: When you write your math story, make sure it's super clear so someone else can understand it, just like the stories we read! You need to write down what happens and then ask a question at the very end. That way, your grown-up can try to solve your puzzle!

slides.prompt: Write 4 word problems — one for each operation. Then trade with your parent and solve each other's problems. Check your answers together!
slides.mascot_explanation: Now for the super fun part! We're going to write four math stories, one for each math idea we talked about. Then, we'll swap them with your grown-up, and you'll solve their stories, and they'll solve yours! It's like a math game where we help each other.

slides.text: 'Writing word problems is HARDER than solving them because you have to think about the math AND the story. You did it!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child create a solvable word problem for each of the four operations with correct mathematical reasoning?
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, you did it! You made up your very own math stories, which is even trickier than solving them! You had to think about the numbers *and* make a good story. That shows you're a super strong mathematician and a brilliant author. You should be so proud of yourself!

parent_notes: Creating word problems requires the deepest level of mathematical understanding because the child must construct a scenario that accurately represents a mathematical operation. This is Bloom's taxonomy at its highest level — creating, not just remembering or applying. When you solve the child's problems, model the thinking process: 'Let me read your problem. Hmm, you said 12 cookies shared among 4 friends — that is division! 12 / 4 = 3. Each friend gets 3!' If the child's problem contains an error (a subtraction story with addition words), gently point it out: 'I got confused because you said altogether — usually that means addition. But your story is about giving away.' This feedback refines their understanding.

title: The Skeletal System — Joints and Movement
description: The child explores different types of joints in the human body, discovering how joints allow bones to move in different ways. Hands-on exploration of hinge joints, ball-and-socket joints, and pivot joints.
instructions:
1. 'You know your bones. Today we learn about JOINTS — the places where bones meet and can move!'
2. Explore hinge joints: bend the elbow. 'This only moves ONE way, like a door hinge.'
3. Explore ball-and-socket joints: rotate the shoulder. 'This moves in CIRCLES, like a joystick!'
4. Explore pivot joints: turn the head. 'This lets you rotate, like saying no.'
5. Explore gliding joints: move the wrist. 'These slide over each other.'
6. Find and classify joints on the body: knee (hinge), hip (ball-and-socket), neck (pivot), wrist (gliding).
7. Add joint locations to the body map with colored dots.
materials_needed: Colored dot stickers (4 colors for 4 joint types)
A door hinge and ball (for comparison)

slides.heading: Joints and Movement
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at this! It says "Joints and Movement," and "Where Bones Meet." That means we're going to learn about the special places in our bodies that help us move and wiggle!

items: Door hinge and ball for comparison
slides.setup_instructions: Prepare colored stickers: red for hinge joints, blue for ball-and-socket, yellow for pivot, green for gliding. Have the body map accessible.
slides.mascot_explanation: We need some fun things to help us learn about our joints today! We have a big picture of a body called a "body map," and colorful stickers to put on it. We also have a picture that shows how joints work, and a special journal. And look, we have a real door hinge and a ball to help us see how some joints move! Ask a grown-up to help you find these.

slides.text: 'Without joints, your body would be one stiff piece — like a robot made of wood! Joints let your bones MOVE in different ways.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Imagine if you were a stiff wooden robot! You couldn't even bend your arms or legs. Our joints are super important because they let us bend and twist and move all around, not just be stuck like a robot!

slides.text: 'HINGE joints move ONE way, like a door. Bend your elbow — it only goes back and forth! Your knee is a hinge too.' Show a real door hinge.
slides.mascot_explanation: See this picture? It's showing a hinge joint, like on a door! Try bending your elbow right now. See how it only goes one way, back and forth? That's a hinge joint, just like a door opening and closing. Your knee does that too!

slides.text: 'BALL-AND-SOCKET joints move in CIRCLES. Rotate your arm from the shoulder — it goes around and around! Your hip is a ball-and-socket too.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, let's try moving our shoulder. Swish, swish, swish! See how your arm can go all the way around in a big circle? That's called a ball-and-socket joint, and it lets you make big circles with your arm, kind of like moving a joystick! Your hip works the same way.

slides.text: 'PIVOT joints let you ROTATE. Turn your head left and right — that is your neck's pivot joint. GLIDING joints in your wrist let bones slide over each other.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's try turning our head side to side. This is called a pivot joint, and it lets you twist your head like you're saying "no" or looking around. And when you wiggle your wrist, those bones are sliding over each other in a gliding joint!

slides.prompt: Place colored stickers on your body map: red for hinge joints (elbow, knee), blue for ball-and-socket (shoulder, hip), yellow for pivot (neck), green for gliding (wrist, ankle).
slides.mascot_explanation: Now for the fun part! We get to put stickers on our body map to show where all the different joints are. We'll use red stickers for the hinge joints in our elbows and knees, blue for the ball-and-socket joints in our shoulders and hips, yellow for the pivot joint in our neck, and green for the gliding joints in our wrists.

slides.text: 'You have 4 types of joints working together so you can move, dance, run, and play. Your body is an amazing machine!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child name and demonstrate at least 3 types of joints and identify examples of each on their own body?
slides.mascot_explanation: Yay, we did it! You learned all about the amazing joints in your body that help you run, jump, dance, and play! You found hinge joints, ball-and-socket joints, pivot joints, and gliding joints and put them on the map – you're a super scientist!

parent_notes: Joint exploration is enormously satisfying for children because every concept can be tested on their own body in real time. The comparison objects (door hinge, ball-in-socket) make abstract joint types concrete. Children often spontaneously start testing every joint they can find: 'Is my finger a hinge joint? YES! Is my thumb different? It moves in more directions!' Encourage this investigation. The colored stickers on the body map create a beautiful layered anatomy project showing bones AND joints. If your child is interested in going deeper, discuss why joints sometimes hurt (inflammation), what cartilage does (cushioning between bones), and how exercise keeps joints healthy.

title: Articulated Skeleton Puppet — Moving Art
description: The child creates an articulated skeleton puppet with movable joints using paper fasteners (brads). This art project directly reinforces the science lesson on joints and demonstrates how joints create movement.
instructions:
1. 'Let's make a skeleton that can MOVE! We will use paper fasteners at the joints.'
2. Pre-cut or have the child cut skeleton parts from white cardstock: skull, torso, upper arms (2), lower arms (2), hands (2), upper legs (2), lower legs (2), feet (2).
3. Connect at joint points with paper fasteners (brads): shoulders, elbows, hips, knees.
4. 'Move your puppet! Which joints bend? Does the shoulder move differently than the elbow?'
5. Decorate the skeleton: add eyes, a smile.
6. Optional: attach a stick to the back for a puppet show.

slides.heading: Articulated Skeleton Puppet
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at this cool title! We're going to make a special puppet today, a skeleton that can move and dance! It's going to be so much fun to build our own moving friend.

slides.setup_instructions: Pre-draw or pre-cut skeleton parts for younger children. Older children can cut their own. Have the hole punch and fasteners ready.
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at all the things we need to make our moving skeleton! We have white paper for the body parts, scissors to cut them out, and these little metal things called paper fasteners that help things move. We also have a marker to draw a face and maybe even a stick to hold our puppet. Can you help a grown-up find all these things?

slides.text: 'We are going to make a skeleton puppet with REAL MOVING JOINTS! The paper fasteners will work like joints.'
slides.mascot_explanation: This is the first step for our super cool skeleton! We're going to make a puppet that can move its arms and legs all by itself, just like you! We'll use these special little fasteners to make its joints work.

slides.text: 'Cut out the body parts: skull, chest, upper arms, lower arms, upper legs, lower legs, hands, and feet.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's time to make our skeleton's body! We need to cut out all the different parts, like the head, the body, arms, and legs. Be careful with the scissors, or ask a grown-up to help you cut them out.

slides.text: 'Now punch holes where the joints are: shoulders, elbows, hips, knees. Push a paper fastener through to connect the pieces.'
slides.mascot_explanation: We're putting our skeleton together now! We need to poke little holes where the arms and legs connect to the body, and then use the paper fasteners to connect them. This is how we make the parts move, like magic!

slides.text: 'Move your puppet! The paper fastener at the elbow works like a HINGE joint — it bends one way. The shoulder fastener moves in more directions!'
slides.mascot_explanation: See how our skeleton can move? The fasteners we put in are like its real joints, helping its arms and legs bend and move. Some joints bend just one way, like a door, and others can move all around!

slides.prompt: Complete your articulated skeleton puppet. Make all joints moveable. Test each joint: does it move like a hinge or a ball-and-socket? Make your skeleton dance!
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's finish making our amazing skeleton puppet! We want to make sure all the joints can move, so try bending its arms and legs. Can you make your skeleton dance and wiggle all around? You did such a great job!

slides.text: 'Your skeleton puppet moves at the joints, just like you do! The fasteners act like real joints — connecting bones and allowing movement.'
slides.mastery_check: Does the puppet have at least 6 movable joints in anatomically correct locations, and can the child identify the joint types?
slides.mascot_explanation: Yay! You made a skeleton puppet that can move its joints, just like you! Those little paper fasteners worked like real body joints to help your puppet bend and dance. You're a fantastic builder!

parent_notes: This art project is a perfect example of Montessori integration — art, science, and fine motor skills combined in a single meaningful project. The paper fasteners physically demonstrate how joints work: they allow rotation at a single point, mimicking the function of real joints. Children will naturally explore the range of motion at each joint and compare it to their own body. The puppet can become a prop for retelling stories, demonstrating movement, or simply playing. Many children take great pride in these puppets and keep them for a long time. This project also develops fine motor skills through cutting, hole-punching, and fastening — all important for writing development.

title: Cooking from a Recipe Card — Preparing a Family Snack
description: The child independently reads and follows a new recipe card to prepare a snack for the family. This second independent cooking experience builds confidence and reinforces the reading-to-doing connection.
instructions:
1. Present a new recipe card: trail mix or ants on a log (celery with peanut butter and raisins).
2. 'You followed a recipe independently on Monday. Today you will do it again with a NEW recipe!'
3. The child reads the recipe card completely before starting.
4. 'What ingredients do you need? Gather them first. What tools do you need?'
5. The child follows each step independently.
6. Serve to the family.
7. Reflect: 'Was this easier or harder than the fruit salad? What made it easier?'
materials_needed: New recipe card (trail mix: cereal, raisins, nuts, chocolate chips, pretzels; OR ants on a log: celery, peanut butter, raisins)

slides.heading: Independent Cooking
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at this! Today we get to be super chefs and make a new yummy snack all by ourselves using a special recipe card. It's like a treasure map for making food!

slides.setup_instructions: Write or print the recipe card with numbered steps. Ensure all ingredients are accessible. The child should gather their own materials.
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at all these important things we need for our cooking adventure! We have our new recipe card, all the yummy food bits, some bowls to mix things in, and even a fun apron to keep our clothes clean. Can you help mommy or daddy find all these things?

slides.text: 'Here is a brand new recipe! Before you start cooking, read the ENTIRE recipe card first. Know what you will be doing before you begin.'
slides.mascot_explanation: This first step is super important for our cooking fun! Before we touch anything, let's look at the whole recipe card together. Reading it all first helps us know exactly what yummy food we're going to make!

slides.text: 'What ingredients do you need? Find them and set them on the counter. What tools do you need? Get those ready too.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, let's be detectives and find all the ingredients and tools! Look at the recipe card and find all the food bits and the special tools we need to make our snack. Let's put them all on the counter so they're ready to go!

slides.text: 'Now follow each step. Check off each one as you finish. If you are unsure, read the step again. You have got this!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Hooray, it's time to cook! We get to follow each step on the recipe card, just like a super chef. We can even put a little check mark next to each step when we finish it. You can do it!

slides.prompt: Read the recipe, gather ingredients and tools, follow each step, and serve the finished snack to your family. Clean up when done!
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's get cooking! We're going to read our recipe, find all our ingredients and tools, and then follow each step to make a super yummy snack. When we're all done, we get to share our special treat with our family, and then we'll clean up our cooking space!

slides.text: 'You read a recipe and made a delicious snack all by yourself! Each time you cook independently, it gets easier. You are a capable, independent person.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child read a new recipe, gather materials, follow steps independently, serve, and clean up with minimal assistance?
slides.mascot_explanation: You did it! You read the recipe, found everything, and made a delicious snack all by yourself! You are such a great cook, and you are getting better and better at making yummy treats all on your own. I'm so proud of you!

parent_notes: Repeating the independent cooking experience with a different recipe builds transfer — the child learns that the PROCESS of reading and following instructions is the same regardless of the specific recipe. This is an incredibly powerful realization: 'I can follow ANY recipe card!' Choose a recipe that is slightly different from Monday's fruit salad — trail mix involves measuring and mixing, while ants on a log involves spreading and placement. Both are achievable independently. The child should gather their own ingredients and tools, which builds the planning and preparation skills they will need for every independent project in their future. Note how much less assistance they need compared to Monday.

title: Sentence Diagramming Introduction — Subject and Predicate
description: The child is introduced to the concept of sentence diagramming by identifying the two main parts of every sentence: the subject (who or what) and the predicate (what they do). This lays the groundwork for grammar analysis in elementary.
instructions:
1. 'Every sentence has TWO main parts: the SUBJECT — who or what the sentence is about — and the PREDICATE — what the subject does.'
2. Write a simple sentence: 'The dog ran.'
3. 'Who is this sentence about? The dog. That is the SUBJECT.' Draw a vertical line. 'What did the dog do? Ran. That is the PREDICATE.'
4. Practice with 5 sentences: 'The cat slept.' 'Mom baked cookies.' 'The red bird sang loudly.'
5. For each, the child identifies the subject and predicate.
6. Draw the simple diagram: subject | predicate.
7. The child writes and diagrams 3 of their own sentences.
materials_needed: Markers (two colors: one for subject, one for predicate)

slides.heading: Sentence Diagramming
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at the big words on this slide! It says "Sentence Diagramming," and that means we're going to learn how to make pictures of our sentences. We'll learn about the "subject" and the "predicate," which are like the most important parts of every sentence.

slides.setup_instructions: Write 5 simple sentences on strips. Prepare the whiteboard for demonstrating sentence diagrams.
slides.mascot_explanation: Oh, look at all these fun things we get to use for our sentence pictures! We have a big whiteboard or paper, some special markers that have two colors, and paper and pencils for writing. We also have these long strips of paper for writing our sentences on. Ask your grown-up to help you get all these ready so we can start our game!

slides.text: 'Every sentence has two main parts. The SUBJECT tells WHO or WHAT the sentence is about. The PREDICATE tells WHAT THE SUBJECT DOES.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Every sentence is like a little story, and every story has two main parts! The "subject" tells us *who* or *what* the story is about, like if we're talking about a puppy or a toy car. The "predicate" tells us *what* that person or thing is doing, like "the puppy barked" or "the toy car zoomed!"

slides.text: 'The dog ran. WHO ran? The dog — that is the subject! WHAT DID the dog do? Ran — that is the predicate!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's look at this sentence together: "The dog ran." Can you guess who this sentence is about? Yes, it's about "the dog"! So, "the dog" is our subject. Now, what did the dog do? He "ran"! So, "ran" is the predicate.

slides.text: 'We draw a line to separate them: The dog | ran. This is called a sentence diagram — a picture of how the sentence works!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we get to make a picture of our sentence! We write the subject, then draw a straight line down, and then write the predicate. See? "The dog | ran." This line is like a fence that keeps the subject and predicate separate, and it shows us how the sentence is built, like building with blocks!

slides.text: 'Try this one: Mom baked cookies. WHO? Mom = subject. What did Mom DO? Baked cookies = predicate. Mom | baked cookies.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's try another one! This sentence says, "Mom baked cookies." Who is this sentence about? That's right, it's about "Mom"! So "Mom" is our subject. And what did Mom do? She "baked cookies"! So, "baked cookies" is the predicate. We would draw it like this: Mom | baked cookies.

slides.prompt: Identify the subject and predicate in 5 sentences. Draw a diagram for each. Then write and diagram 3 of your own sentences!
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's your turn to be the sentence detective! We're going to look at some sentences and find the subject (who or what) and the predicate (what they do). Then, we'll draw our special lines to make our sentence diagrams. After that, you get to be super creative and write and draw three of your very own sentences!

slides.text: 'You can now see the STRUCTURE of a sentence! Every sentence has a subject and a predicate — that is the skeleton of language. See how language has bones too!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child correctly identify the subject and predicate in at least 4 of 5 sentences and diagram them?
slides.mascot_explanation: You did such a great job making pictures of our sentences! You found the subject and the predicate, and you drew the lines just right. You learned that every sentence has a special "skeleton," just like you do, and now you can see how words fit together like magic!

parent_notes: Sentence diagramming at this level is very simplified — just the two-part division into subject and predicate. This is the foundation for the more complex diagramming done in Montessori elementary, where children analyze sentences with multiple parts of speech. The metaphor of the sentence having a 'skeleton' connects beautifully to this week's science theme. The subject is like the skull (the central identity), and the predicate is like the body (the action). Keep this introduction light and fun — the goal is awareness of sentence structure, not rigorous parsing. If the child struggles, use physical movement: 'Stand on the left — you are the subject! Stand on the right — you are the predicate!'

title: Four Operations Review — Math Fact Celebration
description: A celebratory review of all four mathematical operations. The child demonstrates their knowledge through games, challenges, and self-assessment, recognizing how far they have come in their mathematical journey.
instructions:
1. 'You know ALL FOUR operations! Let's celebrate with a math challenge day.'
2. Station 1: Addition flash cards — sort into mastered and learning.
3. Station 2: Subtraction strip board — solve 5 problems.
4. Station 3: Multiplication bead bars — build 3 facts from the 2s, 5s, or 10s table.
5. Station 4: Division board — share beads equally for 3 problems.
6. 'You visited all four stations! Which operation is your favorite? Which do you want to practice more?'
7. Complete a self-assessment: rate confidence for each operation.
materials_needed: Division board with skittles and beads

slides.heading: Four Operations Review
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at this! It says "Math Celebration Day!" That means we get to play some super fun math games today because you are so good at numbers!

slides.setup_instructions: Set up 4 stations around the room, one for each operation. Each station should have materials and 3-5 problems to solve.
slides.mascot_explanation: We need some special things for our math games today! We have cards with numbers, a board with strips, shiny bead bars, and another board for sharing. We also need a paper and a pencil to write down how smart you are feeling! Ask your grown-up to help you find them all!

slides.text: 'Welcome to Math Celebration Day! You have learned addition, subtraction, multiplication, AND division. Today we celebrate by visiting all four!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Yay, welcome to our Math Celebration Day! Remember all those amazing things you learned about adding, taking away, making groups, and sharing? Well, today we get to play with all of them! We'll visit four special spots to practice.

slides.text: 'Station 1: Addition! Answer flash cards as fast as you can. Station 2: Subtraction! Solve 5 problems on the strip board.'
slides.mascot_explanation: First, we're going to Station 1 to play with addition cards super fast! Then, we'll go to Station 2 and do some taking away problems on that strip board. You're going to do great!

slides.text: 'Station 3: Multiplication! Build 3 facts with bead bars. Station 4: Division! Share beads equally for 3 problems.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Next up is Station 3, where we'll use the colorful bead bars to make groups for multiplication. After that, at Station 4, we'll use beads to share things equally with division. So many fun things to do!

slides.text: 'After all four stations, fill out your self-assessment: How confident do you feel with each operation? Star, check, or circle!'
slides.mascot_explanation: When we finish all four stations, we get to do a special paper. It's like telling us how much you loved each math game! We'll use stars or circles to show how super-duper confident you feel about each one.

slides.prompt: Visit all 4 math stations. Complete the work at each one. Then fill out your self-assessment. Which operation is your strength? Which needs more practice?
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's time to be a math explorer and visit all the stations! Do your very best at each one, and then we'll fill out that special paper together. We'll see which math game was your super-duper favorite!

slides.text: 'You have traveled through all four operations! From counting to adding, subtracting, multiplying, and dividing — look how far you have come. You are a mathematician!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child demonstrate proficiency in all four operations using appropriate materials and honestly self-assess their confidence level?
slides.mascot_explanation: You did it! You visited all four math stations and learned so much! From adding to dividing, you are a super math star. Look at how much you know now – you are a real mathematician!

parent_notes: This station-based review is both assessment and celebration. The child physically moves between operations, using the Montessori materials they have worked with all year. The self-assessment is the most important part — a child who can accurately assess their own strengths and areas for growth is demonstrating remarkable metacognitive maturity. Use this assessment to guide future practice: if the child gives multiplication a 'circle' (needs more practice), plan more bead bar work next week. If addition gets a 'star,' celebrate that mastery. This is formative assessment at its best — low-pressure, self-directed, and informative. Photograph the child at each station for their portfolio.

title: The Language of the Body — Sign Language Introduction
description: The child learns basic American Sign Language (ASL) signs, discovering that the body itself can be a tool for communication. This connects the body/skeleton theme to language and cultural awareness of the Deaf community.
instructions:
1. 'All week we have learned about our bodies — bones, joints, and movement. Did you know your body can also TALK? Sign language uses your hands to communicate!'
2. Teach basic ASL signs: hello, thank you, please, friend, I love you, yes, no.
3. Practice each sign with the three-period lesson.
4. 'People who are Deaf or hard of hearing use sign language every day. It is a REAL language with its own grammar and poetry.'
5. Try finger spelling: teach the ASL alphabet for the child's name.
6. The child teaches the signs to a family member.
materials_needed: Mirror (for the child to see their own signs)
Optional: video of ASL being used

slides.heading: Sign Language
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at this fun title! It says "Sign Language" and "Communication with Our Bodies." That means we're going to learn a super cool way to talk using our hands and our bodies, not just our voices!

slides.setup_instructions: Print or display ASL signs for common words. Have the alphabet chart visible. Set up a mirror so the child can watch themselves sign.
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at all these things we need for our signing adventure! We have some charts with pictures of signs, a poster with letters made by hands, and a mirror so we can see ourselves practice. These will help us learn and remember all the new signs we're going to make!

slides.text: 'Your body can communicate without your voice! Sign language uses hands, facial expressions, and body movement to share words and ideas.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Isn't it amazing? Your body can talk! Even without making a sound, your hands and face can tell stories and share your feelings. We're going to learn how to use our bodies to say words!

slides.text: 'Let's learn some signs. HELLO: wave your hand. THANK YOU: touch your chin and move your hand outward. PLEASE: rub your chest in a circle.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's try some first signs together! For "hello," we wave our hand like this! For "thank you," we touch our chin and then move our hand out. And for "please," we rub our tummy in a circle!

slides.text: 'FRIEND: hook your index fingers together. I LOVE YOU: hold up your hand with thumb, index finger, and pinky extended.'
slides.mascot_explanation: We're learning even more signs! For "friend," we hook our pointer fingers together like this! And for "I love you," we make a special hand shape with our thumb, pointer finger, and pinky sticking out!

slides.text: 'People who are Deaf use sign language as their main language. It is beautiful and expressive — just like spoken language!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Did you know that some people can't hear very well, or can't hear at all? They use sign language to talk to each other, and it's a beautiful way to share ideas and feelings. It's a real language, just like when we talk with our voices!

slides.prompt: Practice all 7 signs. Learn to finger-spell your first name using the ASL alphabet. Teach at least 3 signs to a family member.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's time to be a super signer! Let's practice all the signs we learned, and then we can try spelling your name with your fingers, like a secret code! After that, can you show a grown-up at home at least three of the signs?

slides.text: 'You learned a new way to communicate using your amazing body! Sign language shows that language is not just about sound — it is about connection.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child demonstrate at least 5 ASL signs correctly and finger-spell their first name?
slides.mascot_explanation: You did such a great job learning sign language today! You learned that your amazing body can talk without making a sound, and you can connect with others using your hands. You are such a wonderful communicator!

parent_notes: Introducing ASL serves multiple educational purposes: it connects the body/skeleton science theme to language, introduces the child to Deaf culture, and develops fine motor skills and spatial awareness. In Montessori education, learning about different modes of communication builds empathy and cultural awareness. Present ASL not as a 'fun trick' but as a real, respected language used by millions of people. If your child is enthusiastic, explore further: many libraries have ASL story times, and there are excellent children's videos and apps for learning ASL. The I LOVE YOU sign (combining I, L, and Y) is universally beloved by children and often becomes a special family gesture.

title: Read-Aloud: Dem Bones by Bob Barner
description: A rhythmic, colorful retelling of the classic song 'Dem Bones' that teaches skeletal connections through music and repetition. The child sings along, touching each bone as it is named, making anatomy joyful and memorable.
instructions:
1. 'Our last read-aloud this week is a SINGING book! You might already know the tune.'
2. Read/sing aloud: 'The toe bone connected to the foot bone, the foot bone connected to the ankle bone...'
3. Touch each bone on your body as it is named.
4. After one read-through, sing it again with the child leading.
5. 'The song teaches us that all bones are CONNECTED. That is how your skeleton works — everything connects!'
6. Challenge: can the child sing the bone connections from memory?
7. Discuss: 'If one bone is hurt or broken, why does it affect how you move?'
materials_needed: Dem Bones by Bob Barner (or similar skeleton song book)

slides.heading: Read-Aloud
slides.mascot_explanation: Look! This is the cover of our fun book for today. It's called "Dem Bones," and it's all about our amazing bodies!

slides.setup_instructions: This book is best read standing up so the child can touch each bone as it is named. Have the body map nearby for reference.
slides.mascot_explanation: We need our special "Dem Bones" book and a picture of a body to help us. The book is best when we stand up, so we can point to our bones as we sing!

slides.text: 'Stand up for this read-aloud! We are going to SING about our bones. Touch each bone as we name it!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's all stand up super tall! We're going to sing a song about our bones and touch each one as we sing its name. It's going to be so much fun!

slides.text: Read/sing: 'The toe bone connected to the foot bone!' Touch toes, then foot. 'The foot bone connected to the ankle bone!' Touch ankle.
slides.mascot_explanation: Listen to this part of the song: "The toe bone connected to the foot bone!" So, we'll touch our toes, then our feet, and then our ankles.

slides.text: Continue through the whole skeleton: ankle to leg, leg to knee, knee to thigh, thigh to hip, hip to backbone, backbone to shoulder, shoulder to neck, neck to head.
slides.mascot_explanation: We'll keep singing and touching all the way up our bodies, from our ankles to our legs, then our knees, our hips, our back, our shoulders, our neck, and all the way to our head!

slides.prompt: Sing the song on your own! Touch each bone as you name it. Can you do it without looking at the book? Teach the song to someone in your family!
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's your turn to be the singer! Let's try singing the song and touching your bones all by yourself. Can you remember all the parts? Maybe you can even teach it to someone else!

slides.text: 'Every bone in your body is connected to another bone. Your skeleton is one amazing, connected system. You learned so much about your body this week!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child sing or recite the bone connections in order and explain that the skeleton is a connected system?
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, you did it! You learned that all your bones are connected, like a super team that helps you move. Your skeleton is so cool and strong, and you know all about it now!

parent_notes: Ending the week with Dem Bones is pure joy — the song is catchy, the illustrations are vivid, and the repetitive structure ensures retention. This is a perfect example of how music enhances learning: children who learn bone connections through this song often remember them for years. The physical action of touching each bone while singing creates kinesthetic memory. The key anatomical insight is that the skeleton is a SYSTEM — all bones are connected and work together. If one bone is injured, it affects the entire system. This systems thinking is a cornerstone of Montessori education and prepares the child for understanding other systems: ecosystems, solar systems, number systems. Sing this song at bedtime, in the car, and at the dinner table — repetition is how songs (and facts) become permanent.
